awd_titl_txt: Derived Torelli Theorems, Brauer Degeneration and Universality, and Foundations of Algebraic Vision
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports research on several projects in algebraic geometry and allied fields. Focused primarily on solving polynomial equations, algebraic geometry is an ancient subject that plays a key role in numerous fields of mathematics, both pure and applied. It is a linchpin of modern number theory, a heavy hammer of contemporary cryptography, and a crucial input into the computer vision systems that are transforming geography, archaeology, medicine, the automotive industry, and consumer smartphones. While it continues to expand its abstract foundations in astounding new directions, algebraic geometry is also cutting new paths into data science, statistics, and machine learning. The questions under study in this project attack both ends of this spectrum. One part of the project will focus on problems related to so-called Torelli theorems, which seek to capture and quantify the essential linearity of algebro-geometric objects, and on the Brauer group, which is an object that tightly binds algebraic geometry to mathematical physics, non-commutative algebra, and number theory. A second part of the project aims to broaden the algebro-geometric foundations of computer vision, bringing new approaches to deep problems that lie at the heart of cutting-edge applications of computer vision.

The first part of this research project concerns Torelli theorems and focuses on Torelli-type statements for various mixtures of derived categories and Chow theory, building on the investigator's earlier work with collaborators. This is one way of trying to get Torelli theorems in a positive characteristic setting, and the underlying ideas have already paid dividends related to the Tate conjecture for surfaces over finite fields. Research on the Brauer group aims at new degeneration methods via semistable reduction of maximal orders and universality questions for rational Brauer groups of projective spaces. The goal is to gain structural insight into Brauer classes and attack several old problems, such as the cyclicity conjecture. The part of the project on computer vision will introduce functorial methods into the study of multiview reconstruction and resection, leading to new ways of compactifying the natural incidence correspondences that occur in these problems. The work aims to help lay new flexible foundations for algebraic geometry in computer vision that will advance the relationship between the subjects.

por.por_cntn:
This project studied a range of phenomena that fit under the general umbrella of algebraic geometry. Some of the work was focused on difficult foundational questions that relate basic structures of the theory to one another. Other parts of the project were focused on the geometry of computer vision, which is a core technology that is widespread in the modern world.

Algebraic geometry is the study of shapes that can be defined by polynomial equations. For example, a circle can be defined by the equation x2+y2=1 in the plane. One such shape is usually referred to as an algebraic variety. Varieties tend to be very rigid, although they also have a well-understood degree of flexibility. Technically speaking, the deformation space of a variety is finite-dimensional, while other looser geometric structures often come in infinite-dimensional families.

With rigidity comes very delicate geometry. (When something isn't very flexible, it's hard to push it around and learn about its internal structure. Imagine not being able to open a car hood to look at the engine.) One way to study this subtle geometry is through the mathematical shadows it casts. (For example, one could listen for the tell-tale squeal of a loose fan belt even if one cannot open the hood.) One of those shadows is called the derived category. A key part of the project was a study of how much influence the derived category has on the geometry of algebraic varieties. The conjecture this work studied is that the derived category, together with one additional structure, should be enough to capture most of the geometry of a variety.

While no conclusive result was achieved along these lines (although a much deeper understanding of this conjecture was achieved), thinking about it led to some very striking new ways of describing algebraic varieties. In particular, one of the most basic shadows of varieties -- something called the Zariski topological space -- turns out to capture the geometry shockingly often. This was wholly unexpected and is a direct consequence of a failed attempt to prove the conjecture on the derived category. As is so often the case in mathematical research, just as in business and in life, it is the things that don't quite work that end up leading to the most interesting insights.

Another place where algebraic geometry appears in our world is in computer vision, which is the field that specializes in making computers see the world around them. Originally expected to be a simple problem in the 1960s, computer vision turns out to be incredibly subtle and difficult. Interestingly enough, the foundations of computer vision date back to the mid-19th Century, where they co-evolved with early versions of algebraic geometry (what is called projective geometry). The second major result of this project is a collection of new ideas, techniques, and pieces of mathematics that aim to revive the old collaboration between computer vision and algebraic geometry. 

It turns out that the basic objects of computer vision are often algebraic varieties. Using modern techinques to study these algebraic varieties leads to a number of new insights into their structure and flexibility. This project has produced foundations for new algorithms to perform basic calculations that are done billions of times each day on planet Earth. It is hoped that further development of the ideas in this project could lead to refinements of our understanding of these basic calculations and improvements in accuracy and speed. In addition, the techniques introduced in this project could help us understand one of the crucial phase transitions that occur in computer vision (the problem of coincident camera centers), which would have important implications for consumer technology and national security.

One of the key outputs of this project is the training of several graduate students, who have gone on to do research at universities, teach at undergraduate-focused institutions, and work in industry. This project also helped support the PI and his students' organization of and participation in several conferences that brought together workers from academia and industry to discuss computer vision.

The PI is grateful to the NSF for this support, and to the US federal government for its continued funding for basic research and intellectual exploration.
